Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Chemical Science Leadership Initiative (CSLI)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) and the EPSCoR Office at the National Science Foundation supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site led by professors Karl S. Booksh and Sharon Rozovsky at the University of Delaware. The research projects supported at this Site entitled "Chemical Sciences Leadership Initiative" (CSLI), is dedicated to preparing students with disabilities to become tomorrow's leaders in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). The activities of CSLI address psychological and sociological studies on "solo status" and "stereotype threat" that identify the negative consequences of being a minority group member within a large organization and how the negative consequences manifest as decreased performance and persistence in post-secondary education. The goal of the REU is to provide the students with a positive learning experience that delivers the knowledge and skills required to succeed in graduate school despite added pressures derived from external factors. CSLI combines a research experience for undergraduates in a state-of-the-art laboratory with classroom material designed to prepare students for success in graduate school. Available research opportunities span all five sub-disciplines of Chemistry. Additionally, a seminar series and field trips will provide participants with a broader context from which to plan careers and make decisions on graduate school selection options. Following the 10-week summer session, students will present their research at the following spring American Chemical Society National Meeting and Exposition and will be invited to participate in the meeting and activities with the ACS Committee on Chemists with Disabilities.

People with disabilities are a significantly underrepresented minority in STEM. Graduate school has become a critical juncture where STEM students with disabilities disproportionately abandon educational advancement. Although 10% of STEM undergraduate majors and 6% of STEM graduate students have disabilities, only 1% of STEM doctorates are earned by students with disabilities. The REU Site also focuses on mentoring assistant professors in working with coordinated outreach programs in general and mentoring students with disabilities in specific. Of the nine core mentors, seven are assistant professors and two are full professors who will serve dual roles as mentors-to-students and mentors-to-mentors. Assessment will be performed through the Delaware Education Research and Development Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Chemical Sciences Leadership Institute (CSLI) is a unique REU program that envisions preparing chemistry students with disabilities to become future leaders in their chosen fields. The immediate foci of CSLI are research excellence and graduate school preparation. However, significant effort is dedicated to development of career navigation and interpersonal relationship skills that will serve the CSLI alumni beyond the primary prevue of the program. CSLI is unique in that it are the only REU program that broadly addresses disability in chemistry and it is the only REU program addressing disability issues in chemistry at a RUVH. CSLI follows the pre-2010 NSF Survey of Earned Doctorates (SED) definition of disability; each applicant was simply asked if he/she identifies as having a disability. Those responding in the affirmative were deemed eligible for the CSLI program.

CSLI hosted twenty-one (21) chemistry students with disabilities from Summer 2013 – Summer 2015; 3 participants in 2013, 8 in 2015, and 10 in 2015. Overall, the gender distribution was 13 female and 8 male participants. The 62.5% female participant rate is comparable to the 60.7% female applicant pool. Despite our recruitment efforts the pool lacked racial and ethnic diversity leading to only two (2) Asian participants, one (1) Hispanic participant and no black participants. CSLI participants primarily came from small, liberal arts colleges in the Mid-Atlantic region. (Image 1) Most have undergraduate research opportunities available at their home institutions. However only 33% of the students had previously engaged in formal undergraduate research, including two students having prior REU experience.

The students report that the program greatly helped them focus and prepare for their professional careers after graduation. Of the 21 students, 5 are currently in graduate school, three are in industry, two are pursuing professional degrees, two are taking a year to work before returning to graduate school, and the rest have not yet graduated. Two of the students in industry want to pursue and advanced chemistry degree, but did not find a graduate school match for 2016.

 

While all the students have presented their research locally and every student had the opportunity to present at the Spring ACS National Conference, peer reviewed manuscripts with the REU students have been slower to develop. A survey of REU advisors indicates that one manuscript is nearly ready for submission and at least 4 others are planned or in the early writing stage. One student present his research at the Council for Undergraduate Research symposium in Washington DC.

 

During the 3-year tenure of the REU, the PIs have noticed a culture shift within the department. The faculty advisors were happy to bring an REU student into the group, but apprehensive about making accommodations. We had to do quite a bit of training the first year to assuage faculty concerns. The second year, we developed the first University approved protocol to allow service dogs in a chemistry lab. After the second year, faculty and UD students began proactively approaching us for advice on laboratory accommodations. The Vice Provost for Research enthusiastically asked us for help in rapidly obtaining Environmental Health and Safety approval for a student’s service dog in his lab. Prior to the REU the student never asked about bringing in her service dog because she assumed it would be prohibited. By the end of the third yea, faculty are beginning to request students from the REU program. We have admitted 3 of the students to the Department and matriculated 2.
